III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
Section (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
Description following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home as
provided in federal law.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An intensive needs youth was placed into a new foster home
however the foster parents were not informed by the agency all of
the youth’s history, diagnosis, etc. prior to placement.
Investigation Intake worker (IW) through the licensing agency was
interviewed on November 8, 2023, via telephone. IW stated as
part of her role she fields inquiries regarding youth that are in
need of placement. She had received previous emails regarding
Youth A stating he was ready for a community placement. She
reviewed the agency vacancy list previously but did not have a
placement that matched his needs. She stated the license for FP1
and FP2 had recently opened so she contacted them regarding
Youth A. She stated she provided them some information. She
was in contact with Foster Care Worker (FCW) and a family team
meeting was set up that included Youth A, FCW, IW, FP1 and
FP2. During the meeting Youth A and FCW provided some
background information and answered any questions that came
up. She stated after that there was email communication between
FP 2 and FCW. She was included in the emails, but she was not
part of further conversation regarding Youth A being placed with
FP1 and FP2.
Intensive Placement Unit contacted IW regarding Youth A. She
stated they sent her his write up, his MARE video and indicated he
had made a lot of progress and ready for a community setting. In
general, upon receiving placement inquiry emails, IW will reach
out to foster parents that have an opening and explain the
information that was provided to her. Generally, the placement
write up does not have a lot of information. She will reach out to
the assigned foster care worker if more information is needed, or
prospective foster parents have any questions. Once the foster
2

parents and foster care worker connect, she allows the assigned
worker to provide additional information or answer specific
questions about a youth.
Foster Parent 1 (FP1) and Foster Parent 2 (FP2) were
interviewed together on November 15, 2023, via telephone.
FP2 stated their concern was they were not made aware of all of
Youth A’s diagnosis prior to him being placed in their home. She
stated they were not made aware of all of Youth A’s diagnosis
until the day he moved into their home. They were provided a
large amount of documentation and they did not have adequate
time to review and familiarize themselves with. FP2 stated they
were provided the most recent trauma assessment for Youth A but
not other trauma assessments that had been completed. She
stated Foster Care Worker (FCW) and Pine Rest had been
working with Youth A for a long time and they had adequate
opportunities to provide all of the information to them but did not
do so.
FP2 stated they were contacted by their licensing agency
regarding a few youths that were in need of placement. Regarding
Youth A, the agency described his profile and did not have
concerns with him in their home. At that time, the licensing agency
introduced them to Youth A’s foster care case worker. During the
introductory call with FCW there was a discussion regarding Youth
A’s trauma history and diagnostic history. FP2 stated they were
only informed Youth A was diagnosed with ADHD and PTSD.
FP1 stated FCW informed them Youth A was born to an addicted
mother. FP1 inquired if Youth A demonstrates any type of
behavior that may be associated with Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and
was told he does not. Upon review of documentation, they read
Youth A tested positive for opiates including heroin at birth and
that was not disclosed to them prior to placement.
She further explained they were not able to provide the required
14-day notice to the agency due to an emergency situation where
they were not receiving appropriate responses from professionals
involved with Youth A and, as a result, felt unsafe to continue the
placement.
FP2 stated they felt like Youth A’s placement with them was
rushed and reckless. FP2 further explained they felt as though
they were tricked into taking placement and were not adequately
prepared for all of Youth A’s needs and behaviors due to not being
told up front. FP2 stated the medication they were provided for
Youth A did not seem to match all of his needs. In addition,
3

service providers, including home based therapy and
Wraparound, had not started timely.
FP1 stated they had 2 calls with several individuals involved with
Youth A less than one month prior to his placement in their home.
He stated they were not made aware of all of the individuals
involved and their roles until that time.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on November 28,
2023, via video conference. CA stated she was surprised FP1
and FP2 felt they were not provided all of the relevant information
regarding Youth A prior to placement. The agency goal was for
the foster parents to be as prepared as possible. CA stated the
agency held multiple meetings that included FP1 and FP2 as well
as Youth A’s therapist from Pine Rest and the LOTUS program
and tried to include everyone at each step along the way and not
omit anything. In addition, the agency worked to build a support
network for Youth A prior to his placement with FP1 and FP2.
CA stated Youth A was never diagnosed with anything related to
Fetal Alcohol. Over the years there have been questions
regarding this but during his stay at Hawthorn it was determined
there was not appropriate documentation and testing to make this
diagnosis.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed on
November 28, 2023, via video conference. She stated FP1 and
FP2 came to the agency’s attention through an Intensive
Placement Unit search. Once they were identified as a potential
placement the agency was in contact with the licensing agency
initially and then foster parents were brought into the
conversation. There was an initial meeting with the licensing
agency, FCW, FP1 and FP2. FCW provided a lot of information
regarding Youth A’s history and emphasized how intensive his
needs have been historically, especially in community placements.
FP1 and FP2 indicated they were interested in pursuing
placement. At that point, there were phone calls, emails and
meetings where documentation was provided. These contacts
included the therapist at the step-down program, LOTUS. FC
Supervisor stated FP1 and FP2 were focused on prior concern
that Youth A may have been Fetal Alcohol. However, Youth A was
never diagnosed with that. She emphasized some of the
documentation was older and it should be reviewed in a
progressive manner to get a better understanding of Youth A’s
diagnoses and current needs. During his most recent placement
at Hawthorne this was reviewed again, and it was determined a
Fetal Alcohol Diagnosis is not appropriate.
4

Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on November 29,
2023, via video conference. He stated there were numerous
statewide searches for placement. The Intensive Placement Unit
identified FP1 and FP2 as a possible placement. FCW stated he
initially connected with FP1 and FP2 approximately 2 months prior
to Youth A being placed in their home. FCW stated the agency
conducted a 2-month transition prior to placing Youth A with FP1
and FP2. The transition consisted of local visits, multiple emails,
phone calls, and video conference meetings. During meetings
there were numerous discussions regarding Youth A’s behavioral
history and diagnosis. FCW stated he connected FP1 and FP2
with Youth A’s therapist at Pine Rest and was told they had
regular communication. In addition, there were almost daily phone
calls between Youth A and FP1 and FP2 for approximately 2-3
weeks prior to placement as well as occasional phone calls
between Youth A and FP1’s adult daughter. FCW stated he
provides hard copies of documentation that was previously
reviewed at the time of Youth A’s placement with FP1 and FP2.
FCW stated FP1 and FP2 became upset after Youth A was placed
in their home after reviewing documentation that mentioned Fetal
Alcohol Syndrome. He stated that was not shared due to it being
ruled out as a diagnosis while Youth A was placed at Hawthorne.
FCW stated Youth A’s CTAC assessment thoroughly documents
Youth A’s behavioral history and diagnosis, and that document
was provided to FP1 and FP2 by FCW via email in August 2023.
FCW stated he had regular meetings with Pine Rest regarding
Youth A and FP1 and FP2 had been invited to those meetings. He
stated they attended the majority of the meetings once they were
invited so they were aware of the updates.
FCW stated he was somewhat concerned that FP1 and FP2 were
newly licensed and had not had a child placed in the home before.
He stated that he wanted to make sure they had all of the
information regarding Youth A so they were aware of what they
were committing to.
Youth A’s Therapist (Therapist) was interviewed on
December 6, 2023, via telephone. He stated he was Youth A’s
therapist during his time at the LOTUS program. He stated he
attended meetings with FP1 and FP2 present when FCW
discussed Youth A’s history, behaviors and diagnosis. He clarified
the majority of the meetings took place prior to Youth A being
placed with FP1 and FP2. Therapist stated he was also open and
5

honest regarding Youth A’s behaviors during meetings and
discussions with FP1 and FP2 present. He stated he worked with
FCW to coordinate multiple visits between Youth A and FP1 and
FP2.
Documents reviewed:
• Email from Youth A’s assigned foster care worker to
licensing agency intake worker on April 13, 2023. The email
stated: “We have really struggled to find a placement for
him as he has been in multiple residential facilities and two
admissions to Hawthorn Center. He truly has made
SIGNIFICANT progress during this admission at Hawthorn
Center. He was admitted in September 2020 and cleared
for discharge on November 16, 2022. Unfortunately, the
residential facilities have probably labeled him in a negative
light and are not willing to give him a chance. It will take a
very specific trauma-informed foster home to take him
on. The psychologist at Hawthorn Center has informed us
that she would be willing to work with a prospective
placement to learn his triggers and to learn strategies to be
successful with him as he has experienced so much trauma
and loss in his 12 years of life”. Attachments to the email
include a 1.5-page treatment update and recommendation
summary from Hawthorn Center that lists current diagnoses
and medication. Other recommendations state, in part,
caregivers should receive psychoeducation on the impact
of trauma and prenatal substance exposure on children.
Additional attachments include RPU slide with a picture of
Youth A, about me, my interests and take a chance on me
because sections. Third attachment is 11-page
Individualized Plan of Service and Nursing Teaching Care
Plans for Youth A that included a brief summary of why
Youth A entered care and precipitating factors that led to
him being hospitalized at Hawthorn. Final attachment is a
9-page placement search information document that
provides an overview of behaviors, interventions and child
welfare history for Youth A.
• Occupational Therapy Assessment dated 8/3/2023.
Document lists previous diagnoses as Disruptive Mood
Dysregulation, PTSD, ADHD and Reactive Attachment
Disorder. Behavioral history includes physical aggression,
homicidal ideation and threats and behavior disturbances.
Email dated August 14, 2023, documents this was provided
by FCW to FP1 and FP2.
6

• August 14, 2023, meeting invitation. Subject of meeting is
“discussion regarding Youth A-background history”. Meeting
invitation was accepted by FP1 and FP2.
• Social work contact dated August 3, 2023-email between
FCW and FP2. FCW informs FP2 that Youth A has an IEP
for Emotional Impairment
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file. Social work contact dated
September 5, 2023-Documentation purposes. FP1 and
FP2 visited with Youth A today in Grand Rapids. They also
brought their adult daughter to visit with Youth A as she
was leaving for college the following weekend. This was
the first meeting between them. Pine Rest staff
accompanied Youth A during the visit today. FP1 and FP2
took Youth A to AJ's Family Fun Center in Grand Rapids
and then out for lunch. No issues were reported by Pine
Rest staff or by FP1 and FP2. Visit was 3-3.5 hrs.
• September 7, 2023, meeting invitation forwarded to FP1
and FP2. Meeting occurs biweekly to discuss general case
updates, placement search updates, family finding efforts
and aftercare services.
• Social work contact dated September 11, 2023-FP1 and
FP2 attended video conference meeting to discuss case
updates and placement planning for Youth A. He will reach
the end of the 90-day program at Pine Rest on 09/20/2023,
and an extension has been requested. The licensed home
interested in placement and adoption of Youth A were on
the call, and indicated they would feel comfortable taking
placement of Youth A as soon as the end of this month.
The other members of the team agreed. Services in Wayne
County were discussed, as were school accommodations.
Visits and phone calls between Youth A and this family will
continue.
• Email dated September 12, 2023, sent by FCW to FP1 and
FP2. Email included a copy of CTAC assessment
completed on March 24, 2020, as well as most recent IEP.
CTAC assessment reason for referral stated: Youth A’s
mother used opiates and IV drugs (heroin) and possibly
alcohol during her pregnancy with Youth A. He was positive
for opiates and THC at birth. He was neglected during his
infancy and early toddler years due to substance abuse
and mental health issues with his mother who was his
primary care giver. Youth A was removed from his mother's
care at age 2. He was placed in a licensed foster home
until his father was identified and reunified with Youth A.
His father was identified and reunified with Youth A. Youth
A's father worked long hours and the responsibility of
7

primary caregiver fell on his father’s girlfriend. Youth A has
had behavioral issues that made it difficult for him to be
successful in a general ed classroom. At some point in his
first-grade year, he was assessed by Dr. Sloane and
placed in the Trauma Focused classroom at North Ohio
Elementary School. Youth A continued to have behavioral
issues including aggressive outbursts, self-harm, assaults
on others, defiance and overall emotional dysregulation. He
was hospitalized at Havenwyk in December of 2018, after
he threatened to harm himself and attempted to strangle
himself with a cord. Youth A was assessed by North
Country CMH and he and his family began working with
Northern Family Intervention Services through CMH.
Wraparound was also involved. Youth A’s behaviors did not
change despite these interventions. He was removed from
his parental home for physical abuse by his father's
girlfriend and his father indicated he could not meet Youth
A’s needs. Youth A was placed at Teaching Family Homes
of Upper Michigan (TFH) on 09/24/2019. He had severe
behavioral issues while at TFH. Youth A was restrained
almost daily. He was physically aggressive with staff and
youth, damaged property and was generally defiant while
there. On 12/18/2019, Youth A was moved from Teaching
Family Homes at their request. He was placed at Methodist
Children's Home in Redford where he remains currently.
• Social work contact dated September 14, 2023, video
conference-FCW participated in a video conference with
FP1 and FP2, prospective foster parents, to discuss the
details and to answer questions about the weekend visit
with Youth A. Youth A’s therapist at Pine Rest, facilitated
the meeting. FC Supervisor also attended the meeting.
FP1 and FP2 were able to get their questions answered.
They were also provided with a list of medications/times to
dispense, allergies, and other details regarding Youth A.
FCW stated that he would provide the Medical Consent
form to FP1 and FP2 tomorrow in the event of an
emergency. FP2 had documented some expectation and
the proposed weekend timeline, and this was reviewed
during the meeting.
• Social work contact dated September 15, 2023-Weekend
visitation with the prospective foster parents. Youth stayed
at FP1 and FP2’s home from Friday, September 15th, until
Monday, September 18th, for a weekend visit. According to
FP2, Youth A had some issues with falling asleep as he
had not been in the home previously. FP2 stated that she
stayed in Youth A’s room for part of the night so that he
8

would feel comfortable and less fearful. FP2 stated that
she was able to teach Youth A how to make homemade
macaroni and cheese and homemade pizza. The foster
parents also stated that they played a number of board
games, went swimming, and met with some of their
neighbors. FP1 and FP2 also took Youth A to Meijer to
purchase a new radio-controlled car. The foster parents
also sent multiple pictures and a short video to the FC
worker to show that Youth A was having a good time during
the visit.
• Social work contact dated September 18, 2023-FCW met
with the prospective foster parents and Youth A at the
Meijer parking lot on the south side of Lansing in order for
the FC worker to pick up Youth A after a weekend visit to
return Aaron to Pine Rest. FP1 and FP2 reported that they
had a very good visit with Youth A over the weekend. The
foster parents mentioned the various events that they
participated in with Youth A over the weekend. There were
no concerns reported by the foster parents. Youth A
showed the FC worker the remote-controlled car that FP1
and FP2 purchased for Youth A the previous day. FP2
stated that Youth A was medication compliant and that
there were no medications to return to Pine Rest. FP1
mentioned that they did have a family emergency over the
weekend as FP2’s brother in Ohio had a severe stroke.
FP1 mentioned that they did not tell Youth A about this
situation as they did not want him to worry and that they did
not want to end the visit early due to the family crisis. FP1
and FP2 mentioned that they informed Youth A on the ride
from Detroit that they would like to take placement of Youth
A and that they are planning on him moving to their home
on October 2nd. Youth A was very excited to hear this
news.
• Social work contact dated September 26, 2023, video
conference placement change TDM-FCW participated in a
video conference between Youth A’s therapist at Pine Rest,
and FP1 and FP2. Youth A also participated in the final 30
minutes of the video conference. The primary reason for
the meeting was to discuss any safety concerns as Youth A
is transitioning to the foster home as of the following
Monday, October 2nd. Clinical staff at Pine Rest, also
attended the meeting to discuss the details for the
discharge on Monday morning. FCW stated that he plans
to be at Pine Rest at approximately 10:00 a.m. on Monday.
FCW informed the FP1 and FP2 that he plans to be at their
home at approximately 1:30 or 2:00 p.m. FP1 and FP2
9

talked in detail about their weekend visit with Youth A and
there was a discussion about Youth A’s emotions and
activities during the weekend visit. Youth A was very
excited to see FP1 and FP2 by video. Youth A stated that
he was also excited for the placement date to arrive. He
said that he would miss the staff at Pine Rest, but he is
excited to be moving to a foster home. FP1 and FP2
informed Youth A that their daughter plans to be come
home from college in time for Youth A’s birthday on
November 30th and she plans to stay home for
approximately 3 weeks to spend some time with Youth A.
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file. DHS 3307 dated October
2, 2023, with FCW and FP signature. Diagnoses listed are
Disruptive Mood Dysregulation, ADHD-Combined
Presentation, PTSD. History of physical aggression
towards peers and staff at the facilities. Physical restraints
and seclusion have been utilized in the past. History of
abuse or neglect includes exposure to substances during
pregnancy and physical abuse.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there is documentation
within Youth A’s MISACWIS case record that FP1 and FP2 were
provided all relevant information and documentation regarding
Youth A’s history and diagnoses prior to being placed in their
home. In addition, there is documentation within Youth A’s
MISACWIS case record the agency coordinated visits between
Youth A and FP1 and FP2 as well as multiple phone calls prior to
placement in their home. They were also present for meetings
with service providers as well as email communication where
Youth A’s behavioral history/needs and diagnoses were discussed
prior to placement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: Foster parents alleged that the agency failed to fully disclose a foster child's history and diagnoses prior to placement, specifically raising concerns about undisclosed prenatal substance exposure. The agency conducted an investigation involving multiple interviews and a review of documentation, which showed that meetings, emails, and visits had occurred, and that a specific diagnosis had been ruled out. The investigator concluded the agency was in compliance and provided all relevant information. Ultimately, the report found the agency not at fault, determining no violation of the rules occurred.
